# Lecture 4: Layouts 
---

Welcome to Lecture 4! Here's a brief breakdown of today's class.

#### Learning Objectives
---
1. Understand how we can use CSS concepts to achieve multiple layouts for our webpages
2. Specifically, learn how to use floats to achieve multi-column grids
3. Additionally, explore how we can use flexbox to ahieve the same multi-column grids, but with fewer headaches

#### Rundown
---

#### [Warmup](#warmup)
#### [Floats](#floats)
#### [FlexBox](#flexbox)
#### [Practical CSS3 Use Cases](#practical-css3-use-cases)
#### [Multiple Screens](#multiple-screens)
#### [Frontend Frameworks](#frontend-frameworks)

desc.content: An introduction to floats and flexbox as a means for building various webpage layouts

floats.content:
# Floats --- Display methods, while effective, don't go very far in helping us make effective layouts. Floats are a concept (though kind of convoluted) which help us build complex layouts and grids with more ease. ## [Technical Example](http://samantha.fewd.us/#fork/mottaquikarim/FEWD_Floats_Ex) | [Live Notes](http://samantha.fewd.us/#broadcast/mottaquikarim/FEWD_Floats_Ex) #### Exercises --- We will solve these problems after our discussion period. #### [Simple Layouts with floats](http://samantha.fewd.us/#fork/mottaquikarim/FEWD_Simple_Layouts_with_floats) | [Live Instructor Notes](http://samantha.fewd.us/#broadcast/mottaquikarim/FEWD_Simple_Layouts_with_floats) #### [Addding Float](http://samantha.fewd.us/#fork/mottaquikarim/FEWD_Addding_Float) | [Live Instructor Notes](http://samantha.fewd.us/#broadcast/mottaquikarim/FEWD_Addding_Float) #### [Simple Clears](http://samantha.fewd.us/#fork/mottaquikarim/FEWD_Simple_Clears) | [Live Instructor Notes](http://samantha.fewd.us/#broadcast/mottaquikarim/FEWD_Simple_Clears) #### [Using Clearfix](http://samantha.fewd.us/#fork/mottaquikarim/FEWD_Using_Clearfix) | [Live Instructor Notes](http://samantha.fewd.us/#broadcast/mottaquikarim/FEWD_Using_Clearfix)

#### Examples --- We will use these examples to understand the concept at hand. #### [Simple Three Column Layout](http://fewd.us/howdoi/#/problem/4258) #### [Clearfixing the Parent](http://fewd.us/howdoi/#/problem/4702) #### [Practical Example](http://fewd.us/howdoi/#/problem/4927)

#### Important Facts --- 1. How do they work?? 2. A left-floated box will shift to the left until its leftmost margin edge (or border edge if margins are absent) touches either the edge of the containing block, or the edge of another floated box 3. If the size of the floated box exceeds the available horizontal space, the floated box will be shifted down 4. Non-positioned, non-floated, block-level elements act as if the floated element is not there, since the floated element is out of flow in relation to other block elements 5. The root element () cannot be floated 5. An inline element that is floated is converted to a block-level element #### Clears --- 1. This is the anti-float 2. clearing an item (can be a floated or non floated item) will undo the effects of the float 3. if we're smart about how we arrange our tag structures, we don't really need to rely on this too much #### The Collapsing Parent --- 1. float the parent (meh) 2. empty div in markup with clear: both (meh) 3. overflow: hidden or auto (better) 4. clearfix (best)

flexbox.content:
# FlexBox
---

Flexbox is the newest standard which aims to help make it easier to build modern web interfaces with CSS. It's a spec that gives us ways to ["lay out, align and distribute space among items in a container"](https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/a-guide-to-flexbox/).

---
## Intended for wednesday
---




#### Flex container
---

This is the parent of the items you want to flex.

#### Some properties
---

1. display
2. flex-direction
3. flex-wrap
4. justify-content
5. align-items
6. align-content

#### Flex items
---

These are the properties for the children

#### Some properties
---

1. order
2. flex-grow
3. flex-shrink
4. align-self

Also, clear, float and vertical align have no effect on flex'd items.

[More info here](https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/a-guide-to-flexbox/)

practical-css3-use-cases.content:
# Practical CSS3 Guidelines
---

**Learning Objective**: Understand the implementation of CSS3 as a technique for enhancing user experience.

---


Let's talk about **CSS**, or **Cascading Style Sheets**, the language that allows us to define styles and adjustments to default content on our webpages.


**[Exhaustive list of CSS properties and values](http://www.w3schools.com/cssref/)**

#### CSS Use Cases
---

Here are some interesting use cases where CSS3 in particular becomes super handy.

#### Animations
---

You can do some really awesome work with animating your elements.

* **[Spinner](http://fewd.us/howdoi/#/problem/42730)**

* **[Repeating, multiple animations](http://fewd.us/howdoi/#/problem/4270)**

#### Transitions
---

Transitions are animations that are triggered usually by some form of user interaction.

* **[Hover Effects](http://fewd.us/howdoi/#/problem/4268)**

#### Pseudo Selectors
---

Psuedo classes allow us to style specific types of element features, **i.e.** the **:hover** pseudo selector can be used to style an element as the user puts his mouse over it.

* **[Menu Hover Effect](http://fewd.us/howdoi/#/problem/4957)**

Other examples of pseudo selectors: **:visited**, **:after**, etc

#### Overflows
---

Keep track of content and determine how it should behave if there is more content than space in the container.

* **[Overflow Example](http://fewd.us/howdoi/#/problem/4165)**

#### Grids
---

This one is super expansive and you could literally teach an entire course on this. For now, take a look at a few examples / problems to gain perspective on this.

* **[Vertically and Horizontally Center](http://fewd.us/jargon/#/problem/10099)**

* **[Three Column Grid](http://fewd.us/howdoi/#/problem/4258)**

* **[Flex Align/Justify](http://fewd.us/jargon/#/problem/10100)**

* **[Flex Direction](http://fewd.us/jargon/#/problem/10097)**

* **[Flex Wrap](http://fewd.us/jargon/#/problem/10098)**

#### References
---
1. **[Exhaustive Guide to Flex](https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/a-guide-to-flexbox/)**
2. **[CSS Animations Reference](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Animations/Using_CSS_animations)**
3. 
**[Exhaustive list of CSS properties and values](http://www.w3schools.com/cssref/)**
4. **[Exhaustive list of CSS3 properties](http://www.tutorialrepublic.com/css-reference/css3-properties.php)**

frontend-frameworks.content:
# Frontend Frameworks
---

**Learning Objective**: What are front-end frameworks and how do they allow us to create modern, professional looking websites?

---
Frameworks are basically CSS stylesheets that were developed by other people. They are built in such a way that you don't have to spend time and energy building out commonly reusable components like **buttons** and **input fields**, etc

#### Semantic UI
---
Some quick facts:

* They write the CSS and HTML blocks for you, all you do is copy and paste
* With a basic understanding of HTML/CSS, you can easily start building professional looking websites

**Visit their [website](http://semantic-ui.com/).**

**Read the [docs](http://semantic-ui.com/introduction/getting-started.html).**

#### Material Design
---
Some quick facts:

* Built by Google.
* Follows the Material Design spec that a lot of new Google apps now implement (like Google Calendar, Google Inbox, etc).

**Visit their [website](https://getmdl.io/).**

#### Bootstrap
---

Some quick facts:

* Built by your boys over @twitter, it is a framework for quickly building out complex webpages
* Probably **the** most popular front-end framework.

**Visit their [website](http://getbootstrap.com/).**

**Read the [docs](http://getbootstrap.com/getting-started/).**

#### Primer
---

Some quick facts:

* Build by your boys over @github
* Much simpler than bootstrap
* Lighter weight too!

**Visit their [website](http://primercss.io/).**
